overview: This measure appropriates funds for the Judiciary for the fiscal biennium beginning July 1, 2025, and ending June 30, 2027. [11] Operating resource requests center around funding to make permanent or expand three Specialty Courts on O‘ahu, to fully staff the new Wahiawā District Court, an additional District Court Judge and support staff in Kona, cybersecurity and critical technology costs, funding for the Criminal Justice Research Institute (CJRI), and restoration of funding for essential staffing. [10] [10] Your Committee has amended this measure by clarifying operating and capital improvement project amounts and changing the effective date to July 1, 2050. [12]
appropriations: This measure, as amended, appropriates from general funds $198,782,736 (HB400_SD2_SSCR1841_.htm.txt) for Fiscal Year 2025-2026 and $198,855,327 (HB400_SD2_SSCR1841_.htm.txt) for Fiscal Year 2026-2027. [12] Of the general fund appropriation for administration (JUD601), the sum of $1,000,000 (HB400_SD2_.HTM.txt) shall be expended for civil legal services and $750,000 (HB400_SD2_.HTM.txt) shall be expended on legal services for individuals in immigration-related proceedings for each fiscal year of the biennium. [11] [11] General obligation bonds may be issued in an amount not to exceed $12,900,000 (HB400_SD2_.HTM.txt). [11]
assumptions_and_methodology: The Judiciary's budget request reflects its resource requirements for Fiscal Biennium 2025–2027, based on current circumstances and projected resource needs for the future. [10] The request includes funding to make programs permanent, such as the Women's Court Pilot Project, which was established with a three-year pilot that is set to expire at the end of FY 2025. [10] Projections also include costs to staff new facilities, like the Wahiawā District Court which will open to the public in Spring 2026, and to restore funding for positions defunded during the early part of the pandemic. [10] [10]
agency_impact: The appropriations will allow the Judiciary to establish a permanent Women’s Court with 8.0 FTE permanent positions. [10] It will also significantly expand the Truancy Court and EEIP on O‘ahu and make the DWI Court Program permanent. [10] [10] The funding will support staffing for the new Wahiawā District Court, add an additional District Court Judge in Kona to address an extraordinary caseload, and fund a dedicated cybersecurity staff. [10] [10] [10]
economic_impact: The Women’s Court program's goal is to aid participants in bettering their economic conditions and life circumstances. [10] The Judiciary’s civil legal services fund is critical to supporting safety net providers in Hawaii, and the needs of local safety net providers are continually growing. [10] [10] According to the Legal Services Corporation’s Justice Gap Report (2022), low-income individuals did not receive any or enough legal help for 92% of their civil legal problems. [10]
policy_impact: This measure transitions the Women’s Court Pilot Project, established by the Legislature in July of 2022, into a permanent program. [10] [10] It also secures permanent funding for the DWI Court Program, which has been operational since January 2013 with initial federal funding. [10] [10] The bill also appropriates funds for statewide civil legal services and for legal services for individuals in immigration-related proceedings in immigration court. [11] [11]
revenue_sources: General obligation bonds may be issued to yield the amount that may be necessary to finance projects, provided the sum total shall not exceed $12,900,000 (HB400_SD2_.HTM.txt). [11] The bill appropriates funds from general funds (MOF A), special funds (MOF B), and revolving funds (MOF W) for operating expenses. [11] [11] [11] Testimony from The Legal Aid Society of Hawaii requested supplementing the line-item for civil legal services with an additional $1,000,000 (HB400_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt). [10]
six_year_fiscal_implications: The Judiciary requests additional operating resources in the amount of $6.17M in FY 2026, and $6.25M in FY 2027. [10] The request for the Women's Court is $705,416 (HB400_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) in FY 2026 and $705,416 (HB400_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) in FY 2027. [10] [10] For the Truancy Court and EEIP, the request is $188,388 (HB400_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) in FY 2026 and $183,288 (HB400_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) in FY 2027. [10] [10] The DWI Court Program requests $232,412 (HB400_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) in FY 2026 and $237,612 (HB400_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) in FY 2027. [10] [10] The request for a Kona District Court Judge and support staff is $368,943 (HB400_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) in FY 2026 and $360,048 (HB400_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) in FY 2027. [10] Cybersecurity upgrades require $1,175,300 (HB400_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) in FY 2026 and $1,175,300 (HB400_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) in FY 2027. [10] For the Criminal Justice Research Institute, the request is $512,624 (HB400_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) in FY 2026 and $577,058 (HB400_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) in FY 2027. [10] Restoring funding for three positions for the Wahiawā District Court amounts to $192,408 (HB400_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) in FY 2026 and $192,408 (HB400_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) in FY 2027. [10] [10] The total general fund appropriation for the Judiciary is $198,782,736 (HB400_SD2_SSCR1841_.htm.txt) for FY 2025-2026 and $198,855,327 (HB400_SD2_SSCR1841_.htm.txt) for FY 2026-2027. [12] Making programs and positions permanent will create recurring costs beyond the biennium. [10]
operating_revenue_impact: The provided documents do not identify any anticipated impacts on operating revenues resulting from this measure. [10] [11] [12]
capital_expenditure_impact: The sum of $12,900,000 (HB400_SD2_.HTM.txt) is appropriated for capital improvement projects for FY 2026. [11] [12] Projects include $900,000 (HB400_SD2_.HTM.txt) for the Kauai Judiciary Complex Chiller Replacement, $8,000,000 (HB400_SD2_.HTM.txt) for Lump Sum CIP for Judiciary Facilities statewide, and $4,000,000 (HB400_SD2_.HTM.txt) for the South Kohala District Courthouse. [11] [11] The Judiciary received new information that the relocation of the Children’s Justice Center on O‘ahu will require at least $2M (HB400_SD1_TESTIMony_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) more than previously appropriated, which is included in the lump sum request. [10]
fiscal_implications_after_6_years: Making the Women's Court and DWI Court Program permanent will establish ongoing operational costs beyond the 2025-2027 biennium. [10] [10] The restoration of funding for various defunded positions will also create recurring expenses in future fiscal years. [10] Continued requests for funding for civil and immigration-related legal services are likely, as testimony indicates that current resources are not meeting the community's needs. [10]
updates_from_previous_fiscal_note: The total general fund appropriations have been amended to $198,782,736 (HB400_SD2_SSCR1841_.htm.txt) for FY 2025-2026 and $198,855,327 (HB400_SD2_SSCR1841_.htm.txt) for FY 2026-2027. [12] The authorized amount for general obligation bonds for capital improvement projects has been increased to $12,900,000 (HB400_SD2_SSCR1841_.htm.txt). [12] The effective date of the measure has been changed to July 1, 2050, to facilitate further discussion. [12]
fte_positions: The Judiciary requests additional operating resources for 17.0 permanent FTE and 1.0 temporary FTE. [10] To establish a permanent Women's Court, the Judiciary requests funding for eight positions, which is a net increase of one. [10] A request for an additional District Court Judge in Kona includes 4.0 FTE permanent positions for the judge and three necessary support staff. [10]
appropriations_changes: This measure, as amended, clarifies the operating and capital improvement project amounts. [12] General fund appropriations are set at $198,782,736 (HB400_SD2_SSCR1841_.htm.txt) for FY 2025-2026 and $198,855,327 (HB400_SD2_SSCR1841_.htm.txt) for FY 2026-2027. [12] The capital improvement appropriation from general obligation bond funds has been increased to $12,900,000 (HB400_SD2_SSCR1841_.htm.txt). [12]
funding_sources_changes: The authorization for capital improvement projects funded by general obligation bond funds has increased from $9,900,000 (HB400_SD2_SSCR1841_.htm.txt) in the introduced version to $12,900,000 (HB400_SD2_SSCR1841_.htm.txt) in the amended version. [12] [12] Appropriations for operating expenses continue to be funded primarily by general funds (MOF A). [11]
department_impact: There have been no changes in departmental responsibility for expending appropriations; all funds are appropriated to the Judiciary. [11]
reports_required: If any manifest clerical, typographical, or other mechanical error is found in this Act, the chief justice may correct the error. [11] All changes made pursuant to this section shall be reported to the legislature at its next regular session. [11]
pilot_program: The Women’s Court Pilot Project was established by the Legislature in July of 2022 with funding for a three-year pilot that included seven temporary positions. [10] This bill seeks to establish a permanent Women's Court as the pilot is set to expire at the end of FY 2025. [10] [10] The DWI Court Program, operational since 2013, is also seeking permanent funding to continue its services. [10] [10]
sunset_date: The seven temporary positions for the Women’s Court Pilot Project are set to expire at the end of FY 2025. [10] Additionally, funding for a permanent Project Specialist and a temporary full-time Project Specialist position for the Criminal Justice Research Institute ends on June 30, 2025. [10] [10]
effective_date: The effective date of this Act is July 1, 2050. [11] The effective date was changed to facilitate further discussion on the measure. [12]
